description: From Middle English girden, gerden, gürden, from Old English gyrdan (“to put a belt around, to put a girdle around”), from Proto-Germanic *gurdijaną (“to gird”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰerdʰ-. Cognate with West Frisian gurdzje, girdzje, Dutch gorden, German gürten, Swedish gjorda, Icelandic gyrða, Albanian ngërthej (“to tie together by weaving, to bind”).

verbs.description: gird (third-person singular simple present girds, present participle girding, simple past and past participle girded or girt)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bind with a flexible rope or cord.
examples: The fasces were girt about with twine in bundles large.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To encircle with, or as if with a belt.
examples: The lady girt herself with silver chain, from which she hung a golden shear.

entries.meaning: (transitive, reflexive) To prepare (oneself) for an action.
A stroke with a rod or switch.
A severe spasm; a twinge; a pang.
examples: Conscience  […]  is freed from many fearful girds and twinges which the atheist feels.

verbs.description: gird (third-person singular simple present girds, present participle girding, simple past and past participle girded)
